answers: “Battle Hymn of the Republic” (accept “Mine Eyes Have Seen the Glory”)
Robert Lowell [do NOT accept OR prompt on “Amy Lowell”]
parts: Name this American patriotic song by Julia Ward Howe. It is often sung to the melody of “John Brown’s Body,” and its chorus references the “Glory, Hallelujah” folk tune.
“Battle Hymn of the Republic” was written during this war. This war was also the subject of the Allen Tate poem “Ode to the Confederate Dead.”
A Boston monument to the leader of the first all-black regiment “sticks as a fishbone in the city’s throat” in “For the Union Dead,” a poem by this Confessional poet of “Skunk Hour.”
This founder of the Mughal emperor was a direct descendant of Genghis Khan and Timur the Lame. He defeated Ibrahim Lodi at the First Battle of Panipat to found the Mughal empire.
Perhaps one of the most well known accomplishments of the Mughals was this building, built out of white marble. This monument was built by Emperor Shah Jahan as a tomb for his dead wife Mumtaz.
The Taj Mahal sits on the banks of the Yamuna River in this Uttar Pradesh city. This city was the first capital of the Mughal empire.

answers: cancer [accept any more specific answer, such as leukemia or lymphoma]
parts: The ELMO family of proteins that participate in signalling networks were first discovered in Drosophila and in this model organism. This nematode was the first animal to have its genome sequenced.
The POKEMON gene can help cells affected by this condition survive in environments which would normally be lethal. This condition is often treated by chemotherapy and radiation.
The protein called NEMO activates the transcription factor NF-κB [En-Ef-kappa-Bee], a type of this class of proteins. These enzymes are involved in the transferral of phosphate groups.
Name this work by Modest Mussorgsky inspired by Viktor Hartmann paintings. A troubadour is depicted singing in front of the title building in the “Old Castle” movement of this work.
This composer orchestrated Pictures at an Exhibition, as well as his own piano suite Le Tombeau de Couperin.
The “Ballet of Unhatched Chicks” movement of Pictures at an Exhibition was inspired by this Marius Petipa ballet based on a Charles Nodier novella.
Name this economist who worked with Gerard Debreu to create a namesake model used to prove the existence of general equilibrium.
Arrow is best known for this namesake theorem, which was first outlined in Social Choice and Individual Values. This theorem was later extended by the Gibbard-Satterthwaite theorem.
Arrow’s impossibility theorem concerns this practice, stating that systems of this practice cannot satisfy fairness criteria. Elections often feature this practice.
That story, “A Madman’s Diary,” is featured in this man’s collection Call to Arms. He rose to prominence in the aftermath of the May Fourth Movement.
Lu Xun’s story “A Madman’s Diary” was inspired by a similarly titled story from this other writer. who wrote of Major Kovalyov losing the title body part in a different story.
Lu Xun wrote in this language. Older works of literature originating from this country include Journey to the West and Water Margin.
The slave could make their way to a free state through this network of secret routes and safe houses. Despite its name, there were typically no trains involved.
The slave might keep a lookout for these textiles whose patterns may have communicated information to escaping slaves.
Even after the slave escapes to a free state, they might be turned into the authorities by the locals due to this law that was passed as part of the Compromise of 1850.

answers: Greenwich Village [prompt on The Village or Village Voice]
parts: Name this lower Manhattan neighborhood famed for its counterculture. This neighborhood was the focus of an effort by Jane Jacobs to prevent its demolition to build an expressway.
A less successful effort to oppose highway construction in New York City was led by Lillian Edelstein in this borough. This diverse borough is the only one to be located on the mainland US.
Both of those highways were planned by Robert Moses, who also built the Triborough Bridge from Bronx and Manhattan to this large island, which contains the boroughs of Queens and Brooklyn.

answers: cytochrome c [or cyt c, Prompt on “cytochrome”]
parts: Name this toxic anion that contains a triple-bond. It is the simplest ligand in the most widely manufactured form of Vitamin B12, and in organic contexts it is also known as a nitrile group.
Cyanide binds with this metal in the pigment Prussian Blue. This ferromagnetic element is commonly found in magnetite and hematite.
Cyanide is dangerous because it inhibits this protein’s oxidase, which disrupts the electron transport chain. The release of this protein from the mitochondria helps to trigger apoptosis.
Name this sport. In the painting Stag at Sharkey’s, a man with a brown hat smokes on a cigar while he watches two men engaging in this activity.

Both Members of this Club and Stag at Sharkey’s are paintings by George Bellows, a member of this art movement dedicated to depicting scenes of daily city life. Another member of this art movement, Robert Henri, wrote The Art Spirit.
The Ashcan school is an art movement from this city. Bellows’ painting The Clif Dwellers depicts the tenement buildings of this city’s Lower East Side, and this city is also home to MOMA and the Met.
Deni Avidja was the first top 10 overall pick from this country, and his fellow countryman Yam Madar was also selected. Both players played in this country’s city of Tel Aviv.
Yam Madar was drafted by this team, where he could play with All-Star point guard Kemba Walker.

The 2020 Israeli Basketball Premier League Finals MVP was Amar’e Stoudemire, who also recently became an Israeli citizen. In the NBA, Stoudemire played for the New York Knicks alongside this All-Star forward, who is known for wearing hoodies.

answers: Sierpinski Triangle [Accept Sierpinski Gasket or Sierpinski Sieve]
parts: Name these mathematical objects that are self similar, such as the Koch Snowflake.
This fractal is formed by repeatedly dividing each triangle into 4 new equilateral triangles and removing the central triangle. It is named after a Polish mathematician.
This mathematician coined the term “fractal”. He wrote the paper “How Long is the Coast of Britain?'' to discuss fractals with Hausdorff dimension between 1 and 2.
Identify this ruler that the Rising of the North was intended to place on the throne. This monarch was strongly supported by many Catholics.

The Rising of the North was intended to depose this ruler from her throne. This “Virgin Queen” was later targeted by the Babington Plot. This ruler should not be confused with a later queen of the same name who is the longest-serving monarch in British history.

One man from this family served as Queen Elizabeth’s envoy to Mary, Queen of Scots. Another more famous member of this family led a namesake Catholic conspiracy to free Mary, Queen of Scots and have her replace Elizabeth on the English throne.

answers: Nation of Islam [or NoI; do NOT prompt or accept just “Islam”]
parts: Raelism, the “largest UFO religion in the world,” was founded in this country in 1974. After a revolution in this country Maximilien Robespierre promoted the Cult of the Supreme Being.
This predominantly African American religion believes that UFOs are manmade and interprets imagery from the Book of Ezekiel as referring to UFOs. Malcolm X was once a devotee of this religion.

This man has written a steady volume of literature dubbed “space opera” and has claimed that all humans have had innumerable past lives, including those as members of the ancient alien society of Helatrobus.
Name this novel whose “ultraviolent” protagonist Alex undergoes the Ludovico technique as part of an experimental treatment.
A Clockwork Orange is by this author, who wrote of the writer Kenneth Toomey in his Earthly Powers.
Burgess wrote a novel with four movements titled this man’s symphony. GK Chesterton wrote a novel about Auberon Quin titled after this man “of Notting Hill."
Name this character, who stabs his wife Nedda and her lover Silvio at the end of the opera in which he appears.
Canio appears in this Ruggero Leoncavallo opera about a troupe of clowns. This opera is frequently performed alongside Pietro Mascagni’s Cavalleria Rusticana.
Canio is a role for this vocal range. Luciano Pavarotti was a member of a group of three singers with this highest male vocal range, which lies above the baritone.
Identify this play in which Garcin is condemned to a room in Hell with Inez and Estelle. The three are to be each others’ torturers in this play.
This French philosopher wrote No Exit. He is the source of existentialist quotes like “hell is other people” and “existence precedes essence.”
In No Exit, Inez offers to be one of these objects for Estelle. That offer is reflective of the ontological struggle of each character’s perception in their own eyes and the eyes of others.
Name this Southern city, where a bomb exploded inside a parked RV on Christmas Day.
The blast took place near the colloquially named “Batman Building,” which is actually named after this company.
AT&T’s CEO Randall Stephenson quit in July 2020, citing regret over the company’s disastrous acquisition of this broadcast satellite service provider.
5G is transmitted via this radiation. These waves are the longest on the electromagnetic spectrum.
The radio waves used to transmit 5G typically have a higher value of this quantity. The Fourier transform converts between the time domain and this domain.

5G internet is based on orthogonal frequency-division multiplexing, a method of performing this action of varying a periodic waveform. This process is performed on amplitude or frequency to encode messages in radio waves.

answers: Republic of the Philippines [accept Republika ng Pilipinas]
parts: Name this revolutionary leader who was brought back to his country by Admiral George Dewey after the Battle of Manila Bay. This man was the first president of a country that would later gain independence due to the Tydings-McDuffie Act.
Aguinaldo was a member of the Katipunan Society, which fought for the independence of this Pacific island country with capital at Manila.
Emilio Aguinaldo lost the first election of the Commonwealth of the Philippines to this man, who led a government in exile during World War II.
